Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Needles with High Inclination Angle Cutting Edge and Polished Surfaces for High Performance Biopsy

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this project is to improve the fundamental understanding of needle design and manufacturing in order to enable more efficient needle core biopsy. The tissue biopsy length will be increased by optimizing the high-inclination-angle needle cutting edges and smoothing the needle surfaces to reduce friction at the tissue-needle interface and thereby reduce the required cutting forces. This project involves three tasks. Task 1 is to realize simultaneous internal and external polishing of 18-gauge stainless steel needle tubes using magnetic abrasive finishing. Task 2 is to design and machine (i.e., grind and polish) the high-inclination-angle needle cutting edges. Task 3 is to measure the friction force between tissue and the needle interior, develop the mathematical model of the biopsy length as a function of the needle cutting edge and internal friction force, and optimize the needle design and manufacture to give the maximum biopsy length possible.

If successful, the outcomes of this research will reveal the micro-machining (deformation and cutting) mechanisms of soft tissue using the engineered biopsy needles. Modifications to the existing metal-cutting models and observations of new phenomena in cutting tissue can broaden the application of the traditional field of machining to biomedical and healthcare components. Biopsy is a widely used medical procedure in which a tissue sample is cut and removed for examination to identify and diagnose diseases. The improvement in the tissue-cutting efficiency will reduce pain and improve accuracy in pathology diagnosis, and the innovative needle design and manufacturing will be translatable to any field of medicine that uses needles. The research activities will be integrated into graduate and undergraduate courses creating a learning environment that engages the students in the university engineering experience and enhances their long-term retention in engineering careers.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research activities:
    The goal of this research was to build a fundamental understanding of the effects of the biopsy needle cutting edge and surface roughness on the tissue biopsy length. More specifically, we investigated the design and manufacture (grinding and polishing) of a novel needle tip with high-inclination-angle cutting edges and precision magnetic abrasive finishing (MAF) of the inside and outside surfaces of 18-gauge needles, the most commonly used needles for biopsy procedures. The interaction of tissue with the high-inclination-angle cutting edge and the friction between the tissue and the needle interior was studied. The needle geometry and surface roughness were optimized using mathematical models to maximize the tissue biopsy length. This project involved three tasks. In Task 1, MAF was studied for simultaneous polishing of the internal and external surfaces of 18-gauge stainless steel needle tubes (UF). Task 2 included the design, grinding, and polishing of the high-inclination-angle needle cutting edges (UM). Task 3 included measurement of the friction force and development of a mathematical model of the relationship between the biopsy length and the needle cutting edge and internal friction force. We used the developed model to determine the needle with maximum biopsy length (UM and UF).
    This project provided fundamental information about the needle insertion force (including cutting force and needle-tissue interaction force), effects of the needle surface conditions on the needle-tissue interaction, and the mechanism behind the suction of tissue into the needle. This knowledge is translatable to other medical areas that involve needles.  Based on the findings, this project included the design and fabrication of a new core needle biopsy system, which enables obtaining biopsy samples in better shape with less pain. This will help improve the accuracy of a wide range of diagnoses that require biopsy procedures.
    The findings were disseminated to manufacturing communities through three journal papers (two refereed papers and one non-refereed paper), two conference proceedings, five posters, a doctoral dissertation, an undergraduate honors thesis, and four patent applications (two domestic and two international). (Note: One of the poster presentations received the second place in the competitions.) The findings were also disseminated in five invited seminars given by Dr. Greenslet.

Education activities:
1. Student Scholars
    The primary education activity provided opportunities for research experience for three graduate students (one PhD and two MS students) and two undergraduate students. Four of the recruited students were from underrepresented groups, which were targeted for recruitment. The graduate students mentored the undergraduate students, which broadened the educational experience for all students. In addition to the experimental work in the laboratory, students learned how to summarize and present the results of their research to diverse audiences. Internal meetings gave the students opportunities to exchange their ideas, comments, and suggestions with their laboratory colleagues. External presentations at conferences gave students chances to discuss their research with professional researchers and engineers, which improved the students? knowledge and cultivate their fundamental sense of engineering and research.

2.  Integration of Research into the Classroom
    The results of this research project have been integrated into one undergraduate and two graduate courses, which have been taken by over 580 students. Dr. Greenslet hosted open laboratory events several times for the students enrolled in her classes. These open houses included demonstrations of the magnetic abrasive finishing process for needles in addition to other technologies in the laboratory. These demonstrations allowed students to see the fusion of science and engineering and to experience magnetic abrasive finishing machines and selected precision metrology equipment. These experiences gave opportunities to the students to connect the fundamental skills learned in Mechanical and Electrical Engineering classes to the skills used in the practical world.


3. Outreach:
(a) Annual Florida Junior Science, Engineering and Humanities Symposium (JSEHS)
    The JSEHS program has been bringing Florida science teachers, high school students, and select middle school students to UF since 1963. The main components of this program are visits to research laboratories across campus, a speaker competition for 11th and 12th grade student researchers, and an opportunity for 9th and 10th grade students to give presentations as a practice for future competitions. Students are invited to bring posters to display throughout the symposium. During the project period, Dr. Greenslet hosted over 60 high school science students and teachers to provide hands-on experience with multi-scale (from micro- to nano-scale) manufacturing processes, material science, and magnetism.
   
(b) Student Science Training Program (SSTP) at the University of Florida   
    The Student Science Training Program offers high school students a unique and intensive learning environment designed to provide challenging and inspiring experiences and to stimulate interest in science-related careers. About 100 students participated in this program this year. Dr. Greenslet mentored two high school students in her laboratory for two months each summer.


Last Modified: 09/06/2016
Modified by: Hitomi Yamaguchi Greenslet

More specifically, we investigated the design and manufacture (grinding and polishing) of a novel needle tip with high-inclination-angle cutting edges and precision magnetic abrasive finishing (MAF) of the inside and outside surfaces of 18-gauge needles, the most commonly used needles for biopsy procedures. The interaction of tissue with the high-inclination-angle cutting edge and the friction between the tissue and the needle interior was studied. The needle geometry and surface roughness were optimized using mathematical models to maximize the tissue biopsy length. This project involved three tasks. In Task 1, MAF was studied for simultaneous polishing of the internal and external surfaces of 18-gauge stainless steel needle tubes (UF). Task 2 included the design, grinding, and polishing of the high-inclination-angle needle cutting edges (UM). Task 3 included measurement of the friction force and development of a mathematical model of the relationship between the biopsy length and the needle cutting edge and internal friction force. We used the developed model to determine the needle with maximum biopsy length (UM and UF). This project provided fundamental information about the needle insertion force (including cutting force and needle-tissue interaction force), effects of the needle surface conditions on the needle-tissue interaction, and the mechanism behind the suction of tissue into the needle. This knowledge is translatable to other medical areas that involve needles. Based on the findings, this project included the design and fabrication of a new core needle biopsy system, which enables obtaining biopsy samples in better shape with less pain. This will help improve the accuracy of a wide range of diagnoses that require biopsy procedures. The findings were disseminated to manufacturing communities through three journal papers (two refereed papers and one non-refereed paper), two conference proceedings, five posters, a doctoral dissertation, an undergraduate honors thesis, and four patent applications (two domestic and two international). Dr. Greenslet hosted open laboratory events several times for the students enrolled in her classes. These demonstrations allowed students to see the fusion of science and engineering and to experience magnetic abrasive finishing machines and selected precision metrology equipment. These experiences gave opportunities to the students to connect the fundamental skills learned in Mechanical and Electrical Engineering classes to the skills used in the practical world. 3. Outreach: (a) Annual Florida Junior Science, Engineering and Humanities Symposium (JSEHS) The JSEHS program has been bringing Florida science teachers, high school students, and select middle school students to UF since 1963. The main components of this program are visits to research laboratories across campus, a speaker competition for 11th and 12th grade student researchers, and an opportunity for 9th and 10th grade students to give presentations as a practice for future competitions. Students are invited to bring posters to display throughout the symposium. During the project period, Dr. Greenslet hosted over 60 high school science students and teachers to provide hands-on experience with multi-scale (from micro- to nano-scale) manufacturing processes, material science, and magnetism. (b) Student Science Training Program (SSTP) at the University of Florida The Student Science Training Program offers high school students a unique and intensive learning environment designed to provide challenging and inspiring experiences and to stimulate interest in science-related careers. About 100 students participated in this program this year. Dr. Greenslet mentored two high school students in her laboratory for two months each summer.
